title: IBM Research
text:
IBM Research is the <a href="research%20and%20development">research and development</a> division for <a href="IBM">IBM</a>, an American <a href="Multinational%20corporation">multinational</a> <a href="information%20technology">information technology</a> company headquartered in <a href="Armonk%2C%20New%20York">Armonk, New York</a>, with operations in over 170 countries. IBM Research is the largest industrial research organization in the world and has twelve labs on six continents. 
IBM employees have garnered six <a href="Nobel%20Prize">Nobel Prize</a>s, six <a href="Turing%20Award">Turing Award</a>s, 20 inductees into the <a href="U.S.%20National%20Inventors%20Hall%20of%20Fame">U.S. National Inventors Hall of Fame</a>, 19 <a href="National%20Medal%20of%20Technology">National Medals of Technology</a>, five <a href="National%20Medal%20of%20Science">National Medals of Science</a> and three <a href="Kavli%20Foundation%20%28United%20States%29%23The%20Kavli%20Prize">Kavli Prizes</a>. As of 2018, the company has generated more <a href="patents">patents</a> than any other business in each of 25 consecutive years, which is a record.
History.
The roots of today's IBM Research began with the 1945 opening of the Watson Scientific Computing Laboratory at <a href="Columbia%20University">Columbia University</a>. This was the first IBM laboratory devoted to pure science and later expanded into additional IBM Research locations in <a href="Westchester%20County%2C%20New%20York">Westchester County, New York</a>, starting in the 1950s, including the <a href="Thomas%20J.%20Watson%20Research%20Center">Thomas J. Watson Research Center</a> in 1961.
Notable company inventions include the <a href="floppy%20disk">floppy disk</a>, the <a href="hard%20disk%20drive">hard disk drive</a>, the <a href="magnetic%20stripe%20card">magnetic stripe card</a>, the <a href="relational%20model">relational database</a>, the <a href="Universal%20Product%20Code">Universal Product Code (UPC)</a>, the <a href="swap%20%28finance%29">financial swap</a>, the <a href="Fortran">Fortran</a> programming language, <a href="Sabre%20%28computer%20system%29">SABRE airline reservation system</a>, <a href="DRAM">DRAM</a>, copper wiring in <a href="semiconductor">semiconductor</a>s, the <a href="smartphone">smartphone</a>, the <a href="portable%20computer">portable computer</a>, the <a href="Automated%20Teller%20Machine">Automated Teller Machine</a> (ATM), the <a href="silicon-on-insulator">silicon-on-insulator (SOI)</a> semiconductor manufacturing process, <a href="Watson%20%28computer%29">Watson artificial intelligence</a> and the <a href="Quantum%20Experience">Quantum Experience</a>.
Advances in <a href="nanotechnology">nanotechnology</a> include <a href="IBM%20%28atoms%29">IBM in atoms</a>, where a <a href="scanning%20tunneling%20microscope">scanning tunneling microscope</a> was used to arrange 35 individual <a href="xenon">xenon</a> atoms on a substrate of chilled crystal of <a href="nickel">nickel</a> to spell out the three letter company <a href="acronym">acronym</a>. It was the first time atoms had been precisely positioned on a flat surface.
Major undertakings at IBM Research have included the invention of innovative materials and structures, <a href="High-performance%20computing">high-performance microprocessors and computers</a>, analytical methods and tools, <a href="algorithm">algorithm</a>s, <a href="software%20architecture">software architecture</a>s, methods for managing, searching and deriving meaning from data and in turning IBM's advanced services methodologies into reusable assets.
IBM Research's numerous contributions to physical and computer sciences include the <a href="Scanning%20tunneling%20microscope">Scanning Tunneling Microscope</a> and <a href="high-temperature%20superconductivity">high-temperature superconductivity</a>, both of which were awarded the <a href="Nobel%20Prize">Nobel Prize</a>. IBM Research was behind the inventions of the <a href="Sabre%20%28computer%20system%29">SABRE</a> travel reservation system, the technology of <a href="LASIK">laser eye surgery</a>, magnetic storage, the <a href="relational%20database">relational database</a>, <a href="Universal%20Product%20Code">UPC</a> barcodes and <a href="Watson%20%28computer%29">Watson</a>, the question-answering computing system that won a match against human champions on the <a href="Jeopardy%21">Jeopardy!</a> television quiz show. The Watson technology is now being commercialized as part of a project with healthcare company <a href="Anthem%20Inc.">Anthem Inc.</a>. Other notable developments include the <a href="Data%20Encryption%20Standard">Data Encryption Standard</a> (DES), <a href="fast%20Fourier%20transform">fast Fourier transform</a> (FFT), <a href="Beno%C3%AEt%20Mandelbrot">Benoît Mandelbrot</a>'s introduction of <a href="fractal">fractal</a>s, magnetic disk storage (<a href="hard%20disk">hard disk</a>s, the <a href="MELD-Plus">MELD-Plus</a> risk score, the one-transistor <a href="dynamic%20random-access%20memory">dynamic random-access memory</a> (DRAM), the <a href="Reduced%20instruction%20set%20computing">reduced instruction set computer</a> (RISC) architecture, <a href="relational%20database">relational database</a>s, and <a href="IBM%20Deep%20Blue">Deep Blue</a> (<a href="Grandmaster%20%28chess%29">grandmaster</a>-level <a href="chess">chess</a>-playing computer).
Notable IBM researchers.
There are a number of computer scientists "who made IBM Research famous." These include <a href="Frances%20E.%20Allen">Frances E. Allen</a>, <a href="Marc%20Auslander">Marc Auslander</a>, <a href="John%20Backus">John Backus</a>, <a href="Charles%20H.%20Bennett%20%28computer%20scientist%29">Charles H. Bennett (computer scientist)</a>, <a href="Erich%20Bloch">Erich Bloch</a>, <a href="Grady%20Booch">Grady Booch</a>,
 <a href="Fred%20Brooks">Fred Brooks</a> (known for his book <a href="The%20Mythical%20Man-Month">The Mythical Man-Month</a>), Peter Brown, Larry Carter, <a href="Gregory%20Chaitin">Gregory Chaitin</a>, <a href="John%20Cocke">John Cocke</a>, <a href="Alan%20Cobham%20%28mathematician%29">Alan Cobham</a>, <a href="Edgar%20F.%20Codd">Edgar F. Codd</a>, <a href="Don%20Coppersmith">Don Coppersmith</a>, <a href="Wallace%20Eckert">Wallace Eckert</a>, <a href="Ronald%20Fagin">Ronald Fagin</a>, <a href="Horst%20Feistel">Horst Feistel</a>, <a href="Jeanne%20Ferrante">Jeanne Ferrante</a>, <a href="Zvi%20Galil">Zvi Galil</a>, <a href="Ralph%20E.%20Gomory">Ralph E. Gomory</a>, <a href="Jim%20Gray%20%28computer%20scientist%29">Jim Gray</a>, <a href="Joseph%20Halpern">Joseph Halpern</a>, <a href="Kenneth%20E.%20Iverson">Kenneth E. Iverson</a>, <a href="Frederick%20Jelinek">Frederick Jelinek</a>, <a href="Reynold%20B.%20Johnson">Reynold B. Johnson</a>, <a href="Benoit%20Mandelbrot">Benoit Mandelbrot</a>, <a href="Robert%20Mercer%20%28businessman%29">Robert Mercer (businessman)</a>, <a href="C.%20Mohan">C. Mohan</a>, <a href="Michael%20O.%20Rabin">Michael O. Rabin</a>, <a href="Arthur%20Samuel">Arthur Samuel</a>, <a href="Barbara%20Simons">Barbara Simons</a>, <a href="Alfred%20Spector">Alfred Spector</a>, <a href="Gardiner%20L.%20Tucker">Gardiner Tucker</a>, <a href="Moshe%20Vardi">Moshe Vardi</a>, <a href="John%20Vlissides">John Vlissides</a>, <a href="Mark%20N.%20Wegman">Mark N. Wegman</a> and <a href="Shmuel%20Winograd">Shmuel Winograd</a>.
Laboratories.
IBM currently has 19 research facilities spread across 12 laboratories on six continents:
Historic research centers for IBM also include <a href="IBM%20La%20Gaude">IBM La Gaude</a> (<a href="Nice">Nice</a>), the <a href="Cambridge%20Scientific%20Center">Cambridge Scientific Center</a>, the <a href="IBM%20New%20York%20Scientific%20Center">IBM New York Scientific Center</a>, <a href="330%20North%20Wabash">330 North Wabash</a> (<a href="Chicago">Chicago</a>), IBM Austin Research Laboratory, and <a href="IBM%20Laboratory%20Vienna">IBM Laboratory Vienna</a>.
In 2017, IBM invested $240 million to create the MIT–IBM Watson AI Lab. Headquartered in Cambridge, MA the Lab is a unique joint research venture in artificial intelligence established by IBM and MIT, which brings together researchers in academia and industry to advance AI that has a real world impact for business, academic and society. The Lab funds approximately 50 projects per year that are co-led by principal investigators from MIT and IBM Research, with results published regularly at top peer-reviewed journals and conferences. Projects range from computer vision, natural language processing and reinforcement learning, to devising new ways to ensure that AI systems are fair, reliable and secure. 
Almaden in Silicon Valley.
IBM Research – Almaden is in <a href="Almaden%20Valley%2C%20San%20Jose%2C%20California">Almaden Valley, San Jose, California</a>. Its scientists perform basic and applied research in <a href="computer%20science">computer science</a>, services, storage systems, physical sciences, and materials science and technology. 
Almaden occupies part of a site owned by IBM at 650 Harry Road on nearly of land in the hills above <a href="Silicon%20Valley">Silicon Valley</a>. The site, built in 1985 for the research center, was chosen because of its close proximity to <a href="Stanford%20University">Stanford University</a>, <a href="University%20of%20California%2C%20Santa%20Cruz">UC Santa Cruz</a>, <a href="University%20of%20California%2C%20Berkeley">UC Berkeley</a> and other collaborative academic institutions. Today, the research division is still the largest tenant of the site, but the majority of occupants work for other divisions of IBM.
IBM opened its first West Coast research center, the San Jose Research Laboratory in 1952, managed by <a href="Reynold%20B.%20Johnson">Reynold B. Johnson</a>. Among its first developments was the <a href="IBM%20350">IBM 350</a>, the first commercial moving head hard disk drive. Launched in 1956, this saw use in the <a href="IBM%20305%20RAMAC">IBM 305 RAMAC</a> computer system. Subdivisions included the Advanced Systems Development Division. Directors of the center include hard disc drive developer <a href="Jack%20Harker">Jack Harker</a>.
Prompted by a need for additional space, the center moved to its present Almaden location in 1986.
Scientists at IBM Almaden have contributed to several scientific discoveries such as the development of <a href="photoresist">photoresist</a>s and the <a href="quantum%20mirage">quantum mirage</a> effect.
The following are some of the famous scientists who have worked in the past or are currently working in this laboratory: <a href="Rakesh%20Agrawal%20%28computer%20scientist%29">Rakesh Agrawal</a>, <a href="Rama%20Akkiraju">Rama Akkiraju</a>, <a href="John%20Backus">John Backus</a>, <a href="Raymond%20F.%20Boyce">Raymond F. Boyce</a>, <a href="Donald%20D.%20Chamberlin">Donald D. Chamberlin</a>, <a href="Ashok%20K.%20Chandra">Ashok K. Chandra</a>, <a href="Edgar%20F.%20Codd">Edgar F. Codd</a>, <a href="Mark%20Dean%20%28computer%20scientist%29">Mark Dean</a>, <a href="Cynthia%20Dwork">Cynthia Dwork</a>, <a href="Don%20Eigler">Don Eigler</a>, <a href="Ronald%20Fagin">Ronald Fagin</a>, <a href="Jim%20Gray%20%28computer%20scientist%29">Jim Gray</a>, <a href="Laura%20M.%20Haas">Laura M. Haas</a>, <a href="Joseph%20Halpern">Joseph Halpern</a>, <a href="Andreas%20J.%20Heinrich">Andreas J. Heinrich</a>, <a href="Reynold%20B.%20Johnson">Reynold B. Johnson</a>, <a href="Maria%20Klawe">Maria Klawe</a>, <a href="Jaishankar%20Menon">Jaishankar Menon</a>, <a href="Dharmendra%20Modha">Dharmendra Modha</a>, <a href="William%20E.%20Moerner">William E. Moerner</a>, <a href="C.%20Mohan">C. Mohan</a>, <a href="Stuart%20Parkin">Stuart Parkin</a>, <a href="Nick%20Pippenger">Nick Pippenger</a>, <a href="Daniel%20M.%20Russell">Dan Russell</a>, <a href="Patricia%20Selinger">Patricia Selinger</a>, <a href="Ted%20Selker">Ted Selker</a>, <a href="Barbara%20Simons">Barbara Simons</a>, <a href="Malcolm%20Slaney">Malcolm Slaney</a>, <a href="Ramakrishnan%20Srikant">Ramakrishnan Srikant</a>, <a href="Larry%20Stockmeyer">Larry Stockmeyer</a>, <a href="Moshe%20Vardi">Moshe Vardi</a>, <a href="Jennifer%20Widom">Jennifer Widom</a>, <a href="Shumin%20Zhai">Shumin Zhai</a>.
Australia.
IBM Research – Australia is a research and development laboratory established by IBM Research in 2009 in <a href="Melbourne">Melbourne</a>. It is involved in <a href="social%20media">social media</a>, interactive content, healthcare analytics and services research, multimedia analytics, and genomics. The lab is headed by Vice President and Lab Director Joanna Batstone. It was to be the company’s first laboratory combining research and development in a single organisation.
The opening of the Melbourne lab in 2011 received an injection of $22 million in <a href="Government%20of%20Australia">Australian Federal Government</a> funding and an undisclosed amount provided by the <a href="Government%20of%20Victoria">State Government</a>.
Brazil.
IBM Research – Brazil is one of twelve <a href="research%20laboratory">research laboratories</a> comprising IBM Research, its first in <a href="South%20America">South America</a>. It was established in June 2010, with locations in <a href="S%C3%A3o%20Paulo">São Paulo</a> and <a href="Rio%20de%20Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>. Research focuses on Industrial Technology and Science, Systems of Engagement and Insight, Social Data <a href="Analytics">Analytics</a> and <a href="Natural%20Resources">Natural Resources</a> Solutions.
The new lab, <a href="IBM">IBM</a>'s ninth at the time of opening and first in 12 years, underscores the growing importance of emerging markets and the globalization of innovation. In collaboration with Brazil's government, it will help IBM to develop technology systems around natural resource development and large-scale events such as the <a href="2016%20Summer%20Olympics">2016 Summer Olympics</a>.
Engineer and associate lab director Ulisses Mello explains that IBM has four priority areas in Brazil: "The main area is related to <a href="natural%20resource%20management">natural resources management</a>, involving oil and gas, mining and agricultural sectors. The second is the social data analytics segment that comprises the analysis of data generated from <a href="social%20networking">social networking</a> sites [such as Twitter or Facebook], which can be applied, for example, to financial analysis. The third strategic area is <a href="nanotechnology">nanotechnology</a> applied to the development of the smarter devices for the intermittent production industry. This technology can be applied to, for example, blood testing or recovering oil from existing fields. And the last one is smarter cities."
Japan.
IBM Research – Tokyo.
The IBM Research – Tokyo, which was called IBM Tokyo Research Laboratory (TRL) before January 2009, is one of IBM's twelve major worldwide research laboratories. It is a branch of IBM Research, and about 200 researchers work for TRL. Established in 1982 as the Japan Science Institute (JSI) in <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>, it was renamed to IBM Tokyo Research Laboratory in 1986, and moved to <a href="IBM%20Yamato%20Facility">Yamato</a> in 1992 and back to <a href="IBM%20Toyosu%20Facility">Tokyo</a> in 2012.
IBM Tokyo Research Laboratory was established in 1982 as the Japan Science Institute (JSI) in Sanbanchō, <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>. It was IBM's first research laboratory in Asia. <a href="Hisashi%20Kobayashi">Hisashi Kobayashi</a> was appointed the founding director of TRL in 1982; he served as director until 1986. JSI was renamed to the IBM Tokyo Research Laboratory in 1986. In 1988, English-to-Japanese machine translation system called "System for Human-Assisted Language Translation" (SHALT) was developed at TRL. It was used to translate IBM manuals.
History.
TRL was shifted from downtown Tokyo to the suburbs to share a building with <a href="IBM%20Yamato%20Facility">IBM Yamato Facility</a> in <a href="Yamato%2C%20Kanagawa">Yamato</a>, <a href="Kanagawa%20Prefecture">Kanagawa Prefecture</a> in 1993. In 1993, world record was accomplished for generation of continuous coherent <a href="Ultraviolet">Ultraviolet</a> rays. In 1996, Java JIT compiler was developed at TRL, and it was released for major IBM platforms. Numerous other technological breakthroughs were made at TRL.
The team led by <a href="Chieko%20Asakawa">Chieko Asakawa</a> (), <a href="IBM%20Fellow">IBM Fellow</a> since 2009, provided basic technology for IBM's software programs for the visually handicapped, <a href="IBM%20Home%20Page%20Reader">IBM Home Page Reader</a> in 1997 and IBM aiBrowser () in 2007. TRL moved back to Tokyo in 2012, this time at <a href="IBM%20Toyosu%20Facility">IBM Toyosu Facility</a>.
Research.
TRL researchers are responsible for numerous breakthroughs in sciences and engineering. The researchers have presented multiple papers at international conferences, and published numerous papers in international journals. They have also contributed to the products and services of IBM, and patent filings. TRL conducts research in microdevices, <a href="system%20software">system software</a>, <a href="security">security</a> and <a href="privacy">privacy</a>, <a href="analytics">analytics</a> and <a href="Optimization%20%28mathematics%29">optimization</a>, <a href="human%20computer%20interaction">human computer interaction</a>, <a href="embedded%20systems">embedded systems</a>, and services sciences.
Other activities.
TRL collaborates with the <a href="List%20of%20universities%20in%20Japan">Japanese universities</a>, and support their research programs. IBM donates its equipment such as servers, storage systems, and so forth to the Japanese universities to support their research programs under the Shared University Research (SUR) program.
In 1987, IBM Japan Science Prize was created to recognize researchers, who are not over 45 years old, working at Japanese universities or public research institutes. It is awarded in <a href="physics">physics</a>, <a href="chemistry">chemistry</a>, <a href="computer%20science">computer science</a>, and <a href="electronics">electronics</a>.
Israel.
IBM Research – Haifa, previously known as the Haifa Research Lab (HRL) was founded as a small scientific center in 1972. Since then, it has grown into a major lab that leads the development of innovative technologies and solutions for the IBM corporation. The lab’s offices are situated in three locations across Israel: <a href="Haifa">Haifa</a>, <a href="Tel%20Aviv">Tel Aviv</a>, and <a href="Beer%20Sheva">Beer Sheva</a>. 
IBM Research – Haifa employs researchers in a range of areas. Research projects are being executed today in areas such as artificial intelligence, hybrid cloud, quantum computing, blockchain, IoT, quality, cybersecurity, and industry domains such as healthcare.
Dr. Aya Soffer is IBM Vice President of AI Technology and serves as the Director of the IBM Research Lab in Haifa, Israel.
History.
In its 30th year, the IBM Haifa Research Lab in Israel moved to a new home on the University of Haifa campus.
The researchers at the Lab are involved in special projects with academic institutions across Israel, the United States, and Europe, and actively participate in numerous consortiums as part of the EU Horizon 2020 programme. Today in 2020, the Lab describes itself as having the highest number of employees in Israel's hi-tech industry who hold advanced degrees in science, electrical engineering, mathematics, or related fields. Researchers participate in international conferences and are published in professional publications.
In 2014, IBM Research announced the Cybersecurity Center of Excellence (CCoE) in Beer Sheva in collaboration with <a href="Ben-Gurion%20University">Ben-Gurion University</a> of the Negev.
Switzerland.
IBM Research – Zurich (previously called IBM Zurich Research Laboratory, ZRL) is the European branch of IBM Research. It was opened in 1956 and is located in <a href="Rueschlikon%2C%20Switzerland">Rüschlikon</a>, near <a href="Zurich">Zurich</a>, <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a>.
In 1956, IBM opened their first European research laboratory in <a href="Adliswil">Adliswil</a>, Switzerland, near Zurich. The lab moved to its own campus in neighboring Rüschlikon in 1962. The Zurich lab is staffed by a multicultural and interdisciplinary team of a few hundred permanent research staff members, graduate students and post-doctoral fellows, representing about 45 nationalities. Collocated with the lab is a "Client Center" (formerly the "Industry Solutions Lab"), an executive briefing facility demonstrating technology prototypes and solutions.
The Zurich lab is world-renowned for its scientific achievements—most notably Nobel Prizes in physics in 1986 and 1987 for the invention of the <a href="scanning%20tunneling%20microscope">scanning tunneling microscope</a> and the discovery of <a href="high-temperature%20superconductivity">high-temperature superconductivity</a>, respectively. Other key inventions include <a href="trellis%20modulation">trellis modulation</a>, which revolutionized data transmission over telephone lines; <a href="Token%20Ring">Token Ring</a>, which became a standard for <a href="local%20area%20network">local area network</a>s and a highly successful IBM product; the <a href="Secure%20Electronic%20Transaction">Secure Electronic Transaction</a> (SET) standard used for highly secure payments; and the <a href="Java%20Card%20OpenPlatform">Java Card OpenPlatform</a> (JCOP), a <a href="smart%20card">smart card</a> <a href="operating%20system">operating system</a>. Most recently the lab was involved in the development of <a href="SuperMUC">SuperMUC</a>, a supercomputer that is cooled using hot water.
The Zurich lab focus areas are future chip technologies; nanotechnology; fibre optics; supercomputing; data storage; security and privacy; risk and compliance; business optimization and transformation; server systems. The Zurich laboratory is involved in many joint projects with universities throughout Europe, in research programs established by the European Union and the Swiss government, and in cooperation agreements with research institutes of industrial partners. One of the lab's most high-profile projects is called <a href="DOME_Microserver">DOME</a>, which is based on developing an IT roadmap for the <a href="Square%20Kilometer%20Array">Square Kilometer Array</a>.
The research projects pursued at the IBM Zurich lab are organized into three scientific and technical departments: Science & Technology, Cloud and Computing Infrastructure and Cognitive Computing and Industry Solutions. The lab is currently managed by Alessandro Curioni.
On 17 May 2011, IBM and the <a href="ETH%20Zurich">Swiss Federal Institute of Technology (ETH) Zurich</a> opened the <a href="Binnig%20and%20Rohrer%20Nanotechnology%20Center">Binnig and Rohrer Nanotechnology Center</a>, which is located on the same campus in Rüschlikon.
